msDesc.head: Ranulf Higden, Polychronicon (English translation by John Trevisa)

summary.seg: The Polychronicon was the last universal chronicle to be produced by a monk in England. Its author – or, to use his own preferred title, its compiler – was Ranulf Higden, a Benedictine monk at the Abbey of St Werburgh in Chester. He coined the title for his work, he explained, 'from the plurality of eras that it encompasses'. Drawing from a wide variety of medieval and classical authorities, whom he listed in his prologue and cited in the text, Higden described the geography of the world in the first book, and its history from Creation through to his own time in the following six books. On occasion, he added his own observations, marking them with his initial 'R'.

Details of Ranulf's life are sparse. His knowledge of and evident pride in Chester and its environs, as well as his fore-name (which was common in those parts), suggest that he was born locally. He probably entered the monastery at an early age and seems to have spent his entire life there. A later inscription in a copy of the Polychronicon records that he died around 12 March 1363/64. The only evidence that Higden ever left the abbey precincts is a royal summons of 8 August 1352, which instructed Brother Ranulf to bring himself and 'all of [his] chronicles and those which are in his keeping' to a meeting of the king's council at Westminster, on business to be explained to him there.

Regardless of the purpose of this summons, it shows the nationwide renown as a historian that Higden achieved within his own lifetime. Indeed, we know from surviving manuscripts and from contemporary records that copies of the Polychronicon were in circulation at Oxford, Exeter and elsewhere before his death. This widespread dissemination was no doubt aided by the traffic of monks between their native houses and the universities, where increasing numbers of them studied, and the development therein of commercial book trades that could readily supply new copies of in-demand texts. The extent of the demand for the Polychronicon through to the end of the 15th century is shown by the survival today of nearly 150 complete or partial copies of the text, as well as a number of fragments.

A further indicator of the Polychronicon's appeal is that it was chosen for translation into Middle English by the Oxford cleric John Trevisa (d. 1402). Supported by his patron, Thomas (IV), fifth Baron Berkeley, whom he also served as family chaplain, Trevisa had begun the work by at least 1385 and completed it on 18 April 1387. Like Higden, Trevisa too made his own interpolations – adding to, querying or even disagreeing outright with his source text – and marked these with his name. He extended the text with a continuation to 1360, and also supplemented it with further prefaces to Higden's own: the Dialogue between a Lord and a Clerk, a fictionalised conversation about translation between his patron and himself, and a dedicatory Epistle.

Neither of these are found in this copy, however, and the loss of leaves means that the text of the translation begins and ends imperfectly. The manuscript is moreover very plain, with the text written on paper in long and densely packed lines of cursive script, and without even simple coloured initials to mark the beginnings of each book or chapter. Some copies of Trevisa's translation, however, were every bit as ornate as copies of the Latin text: those in Cambridge, St John's College, MS H.1 and Tokyo, Senshu University Library, MS 1 are particularly fine productions. That patrons were prepared to commission such lavish ornamentation suggests the esteem in which they held Trevisa's text and the pride they felt in owning a copy (as well as, no doubt, a desire to show off their personal wealth through conspicuous consumption).

Altogether sixteen manuscripts of Trevisa's translation are known, including this one. The vagaries of manuscript survival mean that we cannot necessarily infer that the Latin Polychronicon was more popular than the Middle English rendering: it may indeed be that its circulation was rather limited or, alternatively, that it was primarily among owners whose books were more vulnerable to subsequent loss or destruction. Either way, who these owners were is consequently less well-known than for the Latin Polychronicon. No evidence of medieval provenance survives in this manuscript (though the presence of marginal annotations and content markers confirm that it was read). Copies of the Polychronicon are recorded in contemporary documents, but unless they explicitly state the language in which the text was written we can only speculate as to whether these were copies of the Latin or the vernacular version. Examples might include a 'Ponecronykyll' in the will of John Hamondson (d. 1472), master of St Peter's grammar school in York; another in the will of Robert Scrayningham (d. 1467), mercer of London; and 'a book called Pollicronikon' that was bequeathed to the clerk John Pechell by William de Thorp (d. 1391) of Maxey Castle in Cambridgeshire.

There was, however, no simple division in spoken language or in literature between a Latinate clergy and vernacular laity in late medieval England (although this is often assumed). There are examples of laymen bequeathing copies of the Latin Polychronicon that one may assume in at least some of these instances they had read themselves. For example, John Yorke of Twickenham lent his Latin Polychronicon (now Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Hatton 14) to the Carthusian William Mede of Sheen 'for the duration of his life'; his son, William Yorke, inherited the book and in turn bequeathed it to Sheen forever. Sir John Morton of York (d. 1431) left 'unum librum de Latino, vocatum Policronica, ex compilatione Fratris Ranulphi Monachi Cestriae' to Robert Semer, rector of St Michael le Belfrey in that city. Notably, Sir Thomas Chaworth (d. 1458) of Wiverton, Nottinghamshire, had copies of both versions: he willed that 'Maister Gull have a boke writen in Latyn called Policonicron' (William Gull was master of Clare Hall in Cambridge, 1440-1446), while also bequeathing a copy of an English translation – presumably Trevisa's – to his son, William.

Limited though the manuscript dissemination of Trevisa's text may have been, it gained a further lease of life in 1482, when it was printed by William Caxton. He reworded and emended Trevisa's text, and further extended it to 1460 with his own 'Liber ultimus'. This formed the basis for further printings by Wynkyn de Worde in 1495 and Peter Treveris in 1527. Evidently, commercial demand for the vernacular text at least must have remained sufficiently buoyant to support these ventures, with readers continuing to consume Higden's text – albeit in mediated form, at a couple of removes from the original – two centuries after his life.

Dr James Freeman
Medieval Manuscripts Specialist
Cambridge University Library

list.item: James Freeman, The manuscript dissemination and readership of the 'Polychronicon' of Ranulph Higden, c. 1330-c. 1500 (unpublished PhD dissertation, University of Cambridge, 2013)

msItem.title: Polychronicon (incomplete)
msItem.author: Ranulf Higden
msItem.textLang: Middle English text with Latin headings
msItem.incipit: 1r Isidorus lio 14o. We redeth in stories that Grekes wone [sumtyme] [...] and called the lond [crossed out: of] \the/ grete grecia that lond hight sumtyme [hesperia of hes]perea the sterre that led the grekes whan they seyled theder [and] was [theyr] loode sterre hespera that is venus
msItem.explicit: 182v Also he warned ffrederyk themperour þat other kynges whiche wente to þe holy londe þat þey shuld not profyte there but lityll at þat tyme . ffor þe tyme of þe delyueraunce wase not þit commyn . Men seith also þat þis Joachym þat he descryued as it were by prophecye þe maners
msItem.note: The translation of Ranulf Higden's Polychronicon by John Trevisa (d. 1402)Trevisa, John, -1402, incomplete: beginning imperfectly in Book 1, Chapter 3 and ending imperfectly in Book 7, Chapter 22. Waldron (1990) notes that parts of chapters 9 and 10 of Book 6 are missing, as well as a large section begining with the end of chapter 29 of Book 6 and continuing until within Chapter 14 of Book 7. As Rand (2009) notes, the text contains the Minor Version of the text in Chapters 14-25 of Book 6.
Damage caused by damp occasionally affects the legibility of the manuscript. The transcribed words for the text's incipit in this catalogue record have been supplied with the aid of UV light.
The text on f. 77v and f. 123r has been written upside down.

msItem.title: Medical recipe (unfinished)
msItem.incipit: 98v Take betayne / Take betayne mylfoile or yarrowe ferwyn and cammamell comyn
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.title: Monogram of the initials I.S.
msItem.note: Drawn (twice) in brown ink; added in the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.title: ? Ownership inscription (unfinished)
msItem.note: Full transcription of erased text. Possibly an unfinished ownerhip inscription, added in the late 15th or early 16th century.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in folio. Folios 1-182: bull's head with star (six-pointed).

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil at the centres of the upper margins.

p.formula: 116 214 312 416-1 (16th cancelled) 516 616-2 (15th and 16th cancelled) 716-2 (15th and 16th cancelled) 812 916-2 (14th and 15th cancelled) 1014 1110-5 (6th-10th cancelled) 1216 1312-2 (5th and 12th cancelled)

signatures.p: Leaf signatures (Hindu-Arabic numerals 1-5) written on the lower margins of the rectos of the first half of the quire.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords (2-3 words) in brown ink in the lower margins of versos, including but not exclusively those of last versos of quires.

condition.p: The original upper part of folio 52 has been removed and replaced with new paper (pasted against the leaf's verso), probably in order to correct an erroneous section of text on either the recto or verso.
The manuscript contians various cancelled leaves as is indicated by the presence of 1 stub after f. 57; 2 after f. 97; 2 after f. 111; 2 after 136; 5 after 156; 1 after f. 176; and 1 after f. 182.

layout.seg: Usually no visible ruling but occasional frame ruling in leadpoint (and blindpoint) visible. Mainly single columns, except ff. 13r (lower part)-15r which have two columns). 27-74 lines to the page, usually written above top line (see Quires 4, 7, 9, 10, 11) but occasionally also below top line (see Quire 5, ff. 61-64).

handNote.p: Copied by at least six (but possibly more) scribes working in cursive scripts with both anglicana and secretary features.

decoNote.p: Inserted into the text space in the lower left corner of f. 60r is a rectancular diagram (measuring 70 x 60mm) in brown ink that shows the relative proportions of three Pythagorean hammers (this is the figure to which the text refers).
Inserted into the text space after the second line on f. 60v is, on the left-hand side, a diagram in brown ink illustrating Pythagorean tuning (this is the fygure to which the text refers).
Cadels in brown ink on elongated ascenders of letters on the first lines of ff. 134v-135r.

Added drawing of the outline of the paper's watermark on f. 139r (nevertheless, the drawing deviates from the watermark in that the staff on the bull's head does not feature a six-pointed star but a 'flag'). This drawing is accompained by an added (?) 16th-century inscription: La belle [...].

note.p: A modern hand has written the quire numbers 1-11, 11a, and 11A are written in pencil in the lower outer corners of the first rectos of quires. However, this hand has continued this sequence by adding the number 12 to f. 178r, which does not match with the beginning of a new quire.

binding.p: The manuscript was disbound in 2007 for digitisation purposes and is currently awaiting rebinding. For the interim period, the manuscript's quires are kept in white paper folders marked with their shelfmark, and respective quire and folio numbers. Together, these thirteen folders are kept in a grey conservation folder with their shelfmark (MS 354) printed and written on it.

The manuscript's former binding - removed in 2007 - is now kept separately from the manuscript. It consists of brown quarter leather over (?) wooden boards with the shelfmark (MS 354 C.C.C.C.) gold-stamped on the spine. This binding, as noted on the recto of its first former flyleaf (f. i recto), was made when the manuscript was rebound by J.S. Wilson and Son at 12 King's Parade, Cambridge, in December 1948. The former binding is accompanied by five former flyleaves, two were located at the beginning (ff. i-ii) and three at the end (ff. iii-v). The former binding measures: 305 x 215mm.

origin.p: Dated 1485-1510, according to Mooney, Horobin and Stubbs, Late Medieval English Scribes (online resource, 2011).

provenance.p: Matthew Parker (1504-1575) Parker, Matthew, 1504-1575, archbishop of Canterbury: the manuscript is recorded as Polichronicon anglice among the libri in minore Bibliotheca on f. 80v of his register of books, now Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 575 [see M.R. James (1912), I, p. xxxix].

history.acquisition: Presented to Corpus Christi College by Matthew Parker (1504-1575) Parker, Matthew, 1504-1575. Catalogued as item 341 in Thomas James's Ecloga Oxonio-Catabrigiensis, printed in London in 1600. Listed as 342 in Edward Bernard and Humfrey Wanley Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ, in unum collecti, cum indice alphabetico printed in Oxford in 1697. Catalogued as item 19.I (see the inner margin of f. 1r) in William Stanley's Catalogus librorum manuscriptorum in Bibliotheca Collegiis Corporis Christi in Cantabrigia: Quos legauit Matthaeus Parkerus Archiepiscopus Cantuariensis, printed in London in 1722. Catalogued as item 354 (see the inner margin of f. 1r) in James Nasmith's Catalogus librorum manuscriptorum quos Collegio Corporis Christi et B. Mariae Virginis in Academia Cantabrigiensis legauit Reverendissimus in Christo Pater Matthaeus Parker, Archiepiscopus Cantuariensis printed in Cambridge in 1777.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, 2 vols (Cambridge, 1912), no. 354; and Kari Anne Rand, Manuscripts in the Library of Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist XX (Cambridge: Brewer, 2009), pp. 88-90. Images and a description of the manuscript are also available on the Parker Library website: Corpus Christi College, MS 354.

availability.p: Visitors to Corpus Christi College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Parker Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Parker Library: Information for Readers.

listBibl.bibl: For a bibliography for this item maintained by Corpus Christi College Cambridge see: Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 354: Zotero Bibliography
